content.webTitle: Troy Deeney looks to restart Watford’s goal machine against Arsenal

fields.headline: Troy Deeney looks to restart Watford’s goal machine against Arsenal
fields.bodyText: If Watford have a cunning plan to end Arsenal’s dominance of the FA Cup when they meet at the Emirates Stadium in the quarter-finals on Sunday, they have been unable to shout too loud about it. That is primarily because their opponents have been plotting their own victory a matter of metres away, with the two training grounds separated by little more than a hedge. “To be honest, although it’s a stone’s throw away, it’s light years away as well,” says Troy Deeney, the Watford captain, whose club are three years into a 10-year lease on their site while Arsenal own the land next door. “We’re here and we’re building, year on year. The [recently opened] media facilities, the gym, it’s getting better year after year. But when you build your own facilities you can have everything straight away. I suppose it shows where both clubs are at this moment in time. They’re established and ready and we’re the new up-and-coming team.” Watford’s momentum appears to have stalled. Seventh at Christmas, they are 13th having won only twice in the league since. Given that only three teams have conceded fewer than their 30 Premier League goals, the finger of blame is being pointed squarely at the attack. Discounting the own-goal Leeds’ Scott Wootton scored in the fifth-round tie at Vicarage Road, the Hornets have found the net in only one of their past seven games. While relegation remains a distant and unlikely prospect, this has nevertheless prompted talk of a crisis of sorts and an unhealthy reliance on Odion Ighalo, who has scored 14 of their 29 league goals but none since January. “In an ideal world everyone would be scoring but it’s just not the way it’s working at the moment,” Deeney says. “But if you stopped the season right now and Watford were on 37 points, in the quarter-finals of the FA Cup, Ighalo’s scored 14 league goals in his first season in the Premier League, does that sound like a bad season to anybody? Although people are trying to highlight certain things, we just have to remember we’re in our first year in the Premier League, having our first proper run in the FA Cup for a long time and we’re doing really well. It’s just because we did so well at the start of the season, now it looks like we’re in a bit of a rut. “A lot of work early doors in the season was based on being solid as a team. We were getting a bit of stick when we weren’t scoring goals and that seems to have come full circle because that’s what people are talking about again now. But the main thing is we’ve been competitive in every match. I don’t think we’ve been spanked in any game. That’s probably the best thing for us.” When Arsenal visited Vicarage Road in October they became one of very few teams to have made Watford appear tactically naive, battling through a fairly even opening hour before scoring three times in a chaotic 12 minutes to end the game as comfortable winners. “That’s the only spell this season when we were too gung-ho I suppose,” Deeney says. “They scored the first goal and, instead of hanging on to what we had for the next 10 minutes and steadying the ship, we went gung-ho and you can’t do that against Arsenal. They just picked us apart and, before you knew it, the game’s 3-0. So we know we have to be cautious, be very smart in our play and, if we do go a goal down, it’s not the end of the world.” One advantage Watford have over Arsenal, who visit Barcelona for the second leg of their Champions League round-of-16 tie on Wednesday, is the ability to concentrate fully on this one game. Given the apparent inevitability of a mid-table finish in the league, many would prefer victory on Sunday to a win in any other fixture. “I don’t know, we’re playing Villa at home next month and we could send them down,” says Deeney, a committed, tattooed Birmingham City fan (his son, Myles, prefers Arsenal), of that idea. Watford’s frustrations in front of goal have not affected Deeney’s self-confidence, even if he has gone from scoring at least 20 times in each of his last three seasons to only four from open play – plus five penalties – this season. “Anybody who knows me knows it’s not about the personal gain this season,” he says. “Would I have liked to score 20 goals? Absolutely, of course I would. But I think Jamie Vardy scored only five goals last season, he’s got confidence from that first year and he’s learned and now he’s the hottest property in English football. I don’t want to compare myself to Vardy, because he’s gone on to absolutely smash it this season and it puts a lot of pressure on me, but I do believe it’s just a case of learning and doing what’s right for the team.”
